bioghist.p: Isaac Lea (1792-1886) was an American conchologist, geologist, and business man, born at Wilmington, Delaware. In 1821, Isaac Lea married Frances Anne Carey (1799-1873), the daughter of Mathew Carey. He entered his father-in-law's publishing firm, and soon became Carey's partner. Henry Charles Lea (1825-1909), Isaac Lea's son, worked for the firm until 1880, when he retired to focus on his scholarly studies. He published numerous articles on various scientific matters from medicine to marine biology, but is best known for his work on medieval history. Isaac Lea's other son, Mathew Carey Lea (1823-1897), undertook a career in law, but abandoned it after several years to pursue a second career in chemistry. His particular interest was in photographic chemistry, and he was influential in laying the foundations for the science of photography.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of volumes and documents related to the Lea family. Materials include: a Lea family commonplace book consisting of prose and verse, some in Latin, with copies of notices and extracts from "Journal of the House of Commons" (1641); Eliza Lea album of verse (some in French) with watercolors, and several papercuts. Includes inscriptions by Robert Owen and the Marquis de Lafayette, dated 1826-1827; Anna C. Jaudon commonplace book, 1845-1848; several scrapbooks on the Lea family, containing correspondence (Henry Charles Lea, Isaac Lea, Mathew Carey, Frances Ann [Fanny] Lea, Maria Carey, Lizzie Lea, J. Henry Lea, and Anna C. Jaudon), typed copy of a travel journal of Thomas Gibson Lea, family trees, obituaries, biographical sketches, travel writings, and pamphlets; Isaac Lea membership certificates and diplomas in various scientific and historical societies and institutions. 1815-1877; Isaac Lea European travel diaries, 1852-53; documents related to the printing business of Mathew Carey, including insurance survey, business correspondence, and book lists; and stamps, medals, and pamphlets.
